nodes.bodyText: why are we getting these warnings? I think the problem is many of these qa tests are trying to disable other features, but we should simply remove those settings from build.gradle in the cluster setup?

             "value" : "val_1"
           }
+      warnings:
+        - "[xpack.ilm.enabled] setting was deprecated in Elasticsearch and will be removed in a future release! See the breaking changes documentation for the next major version."

nodes.bodyText: I agree. I've been trying to identify the specific places where deprecation warnings are thrown in order to make sure that there's nothing important to the tests about having particular settings in build.gradle, but in the case of the watcher tests, the deprecation warnings seem to be happening on index creations and deletions, which doesn't seem relevant to watcher.

To use {transforms} in clients {including {kib}), do not disable this setting on any coordinating nodes.

nodes.bodyText: The deprecation warnings should come before the descriptions.

@@ -28,6 +28,7 @@ For more information, see <<monitor-elasticsearch-cluster>>.
 
 `xpack.monitoring.enabled`::
 Set to `true` (default) to enable {es} {monitoring} for {es} on the node.
+deprecated:[7.8.0,Basic License features are always enabled]

nodes.bodyText: Why is the enrich warning predicated on monitoring being allowed by the license? Shouldn't it be based on the enrich enabled setting being present?

I'm looking forward to getting rid of this. In this test, xpack.enrich.enabled is always set to false. We get a deprecation warning in the case that this setting is checked during the course of the test. However, the EnrichStatsCollector#shouldCollect returns without before checking the enrich setting if the node isn't master or if monitoring is turned off.
In my opinion, this test is a little bit too randomized, making eight different possible cases appear to be a single test. But fortunately I'll be able to get rid of the deprecation warning in a later PR.
I will add a comment for clarity.
nit: this seems more "isExplicitlySet"  (as you have in another test here) than "enabled", since it might actually be disabled
This as well, isn't monitoring.enabled deprecated here?
